Your question is unclear, but I suspect you’re referring to something called “circumlocution,” which is when you use more words than are necessary to say whatever it is that you want to say. The dictionary makes circumlocution sound like a bad thing, but it’s actually a very useful process if you’re trying to learn another language. I’m in the process of learning Spanish myself, and sometimes I just don’t have the right words (or know the exact conjugation ) to say what needs to be said. But, then again, maybe I *can* say what I need to say, if I use additional/other words in order to say it! For example, I want to call my Spanish-speaking wife and tell her “I will be home in fifteen minutes.” Hmm… I know I need to use the verb “estar” (to be) in this context, but maybe I don’t know how to conjugate it into the future tense. So, instead of saying simply: Estaré en casa en 15 minutos. I instead use a verbal phrase that I’m very familiar with that means “I am going to be” _______. Voy a estar en casa en 15 minutos. Granted, there are only two additional words in the second sentence, but that is a short and sweet example of circumlocution.
